string.text: Піскабус is a fine fishing village.
Мультарыбус is a prosperous fishing village.
Альтумдзівіта has a deep silvermine and is one of the reasons Liberatis is such a wealthy trade town.
Порыэль it's a great place to live.
Ніякорыс is a fishing village, located where the Tripotamian plains meet Lake Perasos. The shallow waters here are known for catfish and freshwater sole.
Торыёс sits in the landward side of the coastal Epiric hills, between the sea and the Zeos valley. The lands, woodland that is relatively recently settled, now yield a fine crop of grain.
Ісмілкорг sits in a shallow wooded glen in the hills bordering the Seavorn valley. The villagers harvest oak and fir from these hills.
Джымас sits by a small stream running into Lake Laconys. The thin woodlands and meadows at the dry western end of the lake are good territory for the imperial breeds of horses.
Іорыя sits on a low ridge between the Aris valley and the Vithys. Wheat grows here, fed by the ample rains of the north.
Альберста sits at the base of a key pass over the Carassic massif, the highest mountains in the Empire. It sits atop a narrow ravine, in the sides of which are fine seams of iron ore.
Ортра sits in the foothills of the Dryatic mountains, overlooking a steep canyon. The hillsides have been terraced to allow the growing of crops and mulberry plants on which to raise silkworms.
Вілас sits in the foothills of the Dryatic mountains, overlooking a steep canyon. The hillsides have been terraced to allow the growing of crops and mulberry plants on which to raise silkworms.
Рэндосія sits near the source of the Miron, a river that divides the Carassic massif from the highlands of Visilia. Sheep graze where imperial settlers have cleared away the forests.

Бозантэ sits in Visilia, a sparsely populated plateau region east of the Carassic massif. Silkworm mulberry grows here in the fresh highland air. The dialect here is strongly influenced by Palaic, the language of the tribes in this region before the imperial conquest.

Кэзартл sits at the head of a pass that descends from the plateaus of the imperial highlands to the basin of the Ophthys. Though the steep ravines of the region limit cultivation, wheat grows well in the region's dark soil.
Фэррэла is the center of a rural district on the southern shores of Lake Tanaesis, located amid oak scrub and woodland suitable for the cultivation of mulberry trees used in silk production.
Лавінія sits near an isolated valley in the far southeast of the empire. This frontier zone, long underpopulated due to wars and raiding, still has enough oak to support a thriving forestry industry.
Чанопсіс sits on the wooded ridges overlooking the Tripotamian highlands. Many of the foresters here still speak the languages of the Paleic people, who lived in these lands before the Empire came.
Айсалана sits near where the headwaters of the Sethys come rushing out of a stone outcrop in the midst of the Tripotamian highlands. The chalky soil in these parts makes for fine grazing for horses.
Калавала lies on the rocky eastern shores of Lake Laconys. Rich fishing can be found near the mouths of the streams that flow down from the hills into the lake.

The villagers of Гланта raise small, sturdy cattle on the foothills of Mount Iltan. They include the descendants of refugees and malcontents from across Calradia, seeking isolation in the cold northern forests.
Брэккабі, not as super as Фолтбі.
Калдрус sits on the Skorniva, a stream running out of the northern forests. Like other villages on the river, the people here trade in the salmon who migrate up and down with the seasons.

Кранірог sits in the southern reaches of the Battanian lands, near the source of the Trand River. Warm days, and mornings cooled by ocean mists coming eastward up the river, allow the growing of wine grapes.
Трэландсбі sits on the northern coast of the Lachyar peninsula, bordering the Byalic Gulf. The cold forests here produce an ambudance of berries, that are gathered and dried and sold as spice.
Джернгренд sits where the Seavorn river reaches the Bay of Varcheg. Villagers here tend flax in the cool and misty lowlands.
Пэндраік sits in the southern Rhennod, near Garentor pass. The woodsmen of these hills harvest timbers from the thick forests.

Дзерыят sits where the swift-flowing river the Battanians call the Tryn slows in the lowlands and becomes the Trand. The folk of this region harvest the pines and other trees that grow next to the local marshes.
Мальхарык sits on gentle hills on the lower Trand valley. Cold ocean mists in the morning and sandy soil allow the growing of fine grapes.
Саўрэт lies by the wooded banks of the River Seavorn. The clays of this lowland region provide the raw materials for Battania's famed pottery.
Хормдак lies on the Bay of Varcheg. This end of the bay has few good fishing-grounds, but villagers plant flax on the narrow coastal plain.
Какхавен lies in the gentle wooded hills of the Trand valley. The people of this district are largely foresters.
Брэйтвельд sits on gentle hills on the lower Trand valley. Cold ocean mists in the morning and sandy soil allow the growing of fine grapes.

Файнд sits where the swift-flowing river the Battanians call the Tryn slows in the lowlands and becomes the Trand. The folk of this region harvest the pines and other trees that grow next to the local marshes.
Валанвэлд sits at the mouth of Seavorn river. The cold northern climate and wet coastal lowlands nearby support the growing of flax.
Ўайзенхайм sits on gentle hills on the lower Trand valley. Cold ocean mists in the morning and sandy soil allow the growing of fine grapes.
Майсбур sits in the short stretch of rocky coastline between the mouths of the Cafal and Seavorn rivers. Villagers tend fields of flax in the surrounding floodplains.

Айсенвайлер is a fishing village that sits on a sheltered cove. The sea breezes ensure a mild climate most of the year, and sardines and tuna can be caught in the warm ocean currents coming up from the south, just beyond the headlands.

Ташаўа sits in a ravine in the desert steppe southeast of the Bahr al-Yeshm. Groundwater provides just enough water to grow crops for subsistence, while the village makes its money from rearing horses on the rich but short-lived grass that grows after the spring rains.

Мах Сіф sits in a nook of the bleak hills east of the Bahr al-Yeshm, where the granite rocks of the region trap rainwater in an oasis pool. The farmland is bountiful but limited, and the land is best known for the horses that are grazed on the desert's short-lived but rich spring grasses.

Дэмая, the so-called 'monastery of the winds' named after a colony of ascetics who lived here long ago, sits in the bleak hills southeast of the Bahr al-Yeshm lake. They sink wells where the rocky hills trap rainwater, and cultivate aromatic berries which are dried and crushed and sold as spice.
Пэраўі is a fishing village where the river that the Aserai call the Gabsa reaches the sea. Villagers sail out onto the calm waters of the gulf to seek tuna, sardines, and shark.
Наўмой sits in the rocky edges of the Jebal Tamar hills. The surrounding lands, though dry, produce enough grass in the spring to allow the breeding of horses.

Эрмірын sits just inland of the Gulf of Charas. Prevailing easterly winds from the desert means that the land grows dry quickly, but this allows the cultivation of aromatic berries ground up for spices.
Лечыё sits in the rocky edges of the Jebal Tamar hills. The surrounding lands, though dry, produce enough grass in the spring to allow the breeding of horses.
Джэрані is a village on the right bank of the Damar River, which waters the arid south. The river widens and slows near the lake, and can be used to irrigate fine crops of wheat.

Пеперы sits just inland of the Gulf of Charas. Prevailing easterly winds from the desert means that the land grows dry quickly, but this allows the cultivation of aromatic berries ground up for spices.
Набец sits overlooking a small bay in the Retana, the strip of coastline in the far west of the Aserai lands. Villagers fish for tuna, sardines, and the occasional shark.

Ханаб sits on the plains running from the Jejara Escarpment to Lake Perasos. Like many villages of these parts, it is centered on a rock formation that traps groundwater. The fine clays of this area are brought to the local towns to make pottery.
Ухках sits in a small depression as the narrow plain by the Bahr al-Yeshm lake rises to meet the ridges of the Jejara Escarpment. Clay can be gathered from the local wadis.
Краджык sits in the rocky edges of the Jebal Tamar hills. The surrounding lands, though dry, produce enough grass in the spring to allow the breeding of horses.

Полтанас sits far upstream on the Damar river, not far from its source in the Tair mountains. As the first source of water a traveller coming across the desert would encounter, it is a major source of the spices brought from the lands to the east.

Лівэйгі sits far upstream on the Damar river, not far from its source in the Tair mountains. As the first source of water a traveller coming across the desert would encounter, it is a major source of the spices brought from the lands to the east.

Эначыя sits far upstream on the Damar river, not far from its source in the Tair mountains. As the first source of water a traveller coming across the desert would encounter, it is a major source of the spices brought from the lands to the east.

The oasis of Гердал lies in a depression in the plateau east of the Bahr al-Yeshm. The farmland is bountiful but limited, and the land is best known for the horses that are grazed on the desert's short-lived but rich spring grasses.

The oasis of Пелла lies in a depression in the plateau east of the Bahr al-Yeshm. The farmland is bountiful but limited, and the land is best known for the horses that are grazed on the desert's short-lived but rich spring grasses.
Трыкрыс sits in the edge of the Jebal Tarba, a series of mesas carved by ancient rivers. Pockets of groundwater, trapped by the shifting faults, water groves of date palms.
Майхал sits in the rocky edges of the Jebal Tamar hills. The surrounding lands, though dry, produce enough grass in the spring to allow the breeding of horses.
Герніла is a village on the right bank of the Damar River, which waters the arid south. The river widens and slows near the lake, and can be used to irrigate fine crops of wheat.

Бір Хаўл sits just inland of the Gulf of Charas. Prevailing easterly winds from the desert means that the land grows dry quickly, but this allows the cultivation of aromatic berries ground up for spices.
Эдзікую sits in the rocky edges of the Jebal Tamar hills. The surrounding lands, though dry, produce enough grass in the spring to allow the breeding of horses.
Камклі is a village on the right bank of the Damar River, which waters the arid south. The river widens and slows near the lake, and can be used to irrigate fine crops of wheat.

Мусанас sits just inland of the Gulf of Charas. Prevailing easterly winds from the desert means that the land grows dry quickly, but this allows the cultivation of aromatic berries ground up for spices.

The oasis of Пінлек lies in a depression in the plateau east of the Bahr al-Yeshm. The farmland is bountiful but limited, and the land is best known for the horses that are grazed on the desert's short-lived but rich spring grasses.
Кырканлі sits in the edge of the Jebal Tarba, a series of mesas carved by ancient rivers. Pockets of groundwater, trapped by the shifting faults, water groves of date palms.
The village of Усек and its surrounding hamlets lie at the center of the Devseg plateau, prime grazing lands for the flocks of the Khuzaits and their confederates.
Вомратак and its outlying hamlets lie in a nook of hills on the edge of the Devseg plateau, and are known for the fine clay that can be gathered from their streambeds.
Кіраз is the center of a rural district on the eastern edge of the Devseg plateau, where rain can be trapped in the many shallow valleys and wheat can be grown.
Рокаміл sits in a valley amid the jagged hills that rise north of the Asacys rivers. Its foresters harvest timbers and other goods from the northern woods.
Цогіл and its outlying hamlets lie beneath a rocky ridge on the western edge of the Devseg plateau, in some of the steppe peoples' most prized grazing grounds.

Хурыман lies on the eastern side of Mount Iltan, a volcanic massif that marks the boundaries between the Sturgian and Khuzait lands. The highland pastures are good for grazing, though winters here are harsh.
Камшар sits in the rocky hills near the headwaters of the River Vithys. Seams of iron ore can be found in the limestone ravines cut by the highland streams.
The village of Мазуак sits atop a pass over the Akkan hills. Many of its inhabitants live off the clay that can be gathered from nearby streambeds.
Урджымал sits in a valley amid the jagged hills that rise north of the Asacys rivers. Its foresters harvest timbers and other goods from the northern woods.

Хухер lies near the northernmost part of Calradia where it is still possible to grow grain. Although the local barley makes for a tougher, drier bread than more southerly crops, horses thrive on it, especially the sturdy steppe breeds.
Таослан sits in dry hills overlooking the valley of the River Vithys. Rich seams of iron ore can be found where the streams cut through the shale and limestone bedrock.

Чыкянт lies near the northernmost part of Calradia where it is still possible to grow grain. Although the local barley makes for a tougher, drier bread than more southerly crops, horses thrive on it, especially the sturdy steppe breeds.
Хашут sits in dry hills overlooking the valley of the River Vithys. Rich seams of iron ore can be found where the streams cut through the shale and limestone bedrock.
